intro: Solenandra longiflora, commonly known as the long-flowered screw pine, is a flowering plant native to the Pacific Islands. It belongs to the family Pandanaceae and is characterized by its distinctive, spiral-arranged leaves and fragrant, yellowish-green flowers. The plant typically grows as a shrub or small tree, often found in coastal or wetland habitats. Its flowers are clustered in inflorescences and attract various pollinators, including bees and birds. Solenandra longiflora is also valued for its ornamental appeal and traditional uses in some Pacific cultures.
